translated: Jātaka🔽The Minor Collection
The Chapter with Pairs of Stories
The Uddālaka Jātaka
“Those with rough hides, dreadlocks, and dirty teeth,
with ugly forms, who chant mantras—

original: Kaccinnu te mānusake payoge,🔽Idaṁ vidū parimuttā apāyā”.
analyzed: kaccit nu te mānusake payoge  idam vidū parimuttāḥ apāyā
translated: Are they freed from the lower realms🔽through human effort?
“You commit evil deeds, King,

original: Bahussuto ce na careyya dhammaṁ;🔽Sahassavedopi na taṁ paṭicca,
analyzed: bahu sutaḥ ce na careyya dhamma  sahassa vedaḥ api na tam paṭicca
translated: if you are learned but do not practice the Teaching.🔽Even if you know a thousand scriptures, you will not be freed from suffering

original: Dukkhā pamucce caraṇaṁ apatvā”.🔽“Sahassavedopi na taṁ paṭicca,
analyzed: dukkhā pamucce caraṇam a patvā  sahassa vedaḥ api na tam paṭicca
translated: without practicing.
“Even if you know a thousand scriptures, you will not be freed from suffering🔽without practicing.
I think the Vedas are fruitless,
only practice with restraint is true.”

analyzed: na ha iva vedāḥ aphalāḥ bhavanti
translated: “The Vedas are not fruitless,
only practice with restraint is true.
For one gains fame through the Vedas,
and through practice one attains peace and self-control.”
“Mother, father, relatives—
by whom one is born, that one is.
I am Uddālaka, sir,
of the Sottiya clan.”
“How does one become a brahmin,
how does one become complete?
How is there complete extinguishment,
why is one called ‘firm in Dhamma’?”
“The brahmin who carries fire without a base,
sprinkles water, and raises a sacrificial post,
the brahmin who acts like this is safe,
they have satisfied one who is firm in Dhamma.”
“There is no purification through sprinkling,
nor is one a complete brahmin just by that.

analyzed: na khantī na api sorat ca
translated: Nor is it through patience and gentleness,
nor is one completely extinguished just by that.”

analyzed: katham saḥ brāhmaṇaḥ hoti  katham bhavati kevalī
translated: “How is one a brahmin,🔽how does one become complete,
how is there complete extinguishment,

analyzed: dhammaṭṭho kinti vuccati  a khetta bandhū a mamaḥ
translated: why is one called ‘firm in Dhamma’?”
“The one without relatives to support, without property, without expectations,🔽without greed and bad desires, with greed for existence destroyed,
the one who acts like this is safe,
they have satisfied one who is firm in Dhamma.”
“The nobles, brahmins, merchants,🔽the outcastes, caṇḍālas, and pukkuses,
all gentle and restrained,
all completely extinguished,
among all those who are cool
there is one better and one worse.”
“The nobles, brahmins, merchants,🔽the outcastes, caṇḍālas, and pukkuses,
all gentle and restrained,
all have attained Nibbāna;
For all who are cool
there is no better or worse.”
“Khattiyas, brahmins, merchants,
workers, outcasts, and scavengers;
All are restrained and tamed,
all have attained Nibbāna.
For all who are cool
there is no better or worse;
But you wander for the sake of brahminhood,
for the sake of the lineage of Sottiya.”
“With various kinds of cloth
a mansion is covered;
But for them, the shadows of the cloth
that passion does not arise.
In the same way, among humans,
when young men are purified,

analyzed: te sajātim pamuñcanti  dhammam aññāya subbata ati
translated: they abandon their own kind,
having understood the Dhamma, having good conduct.”🔽The Uddālaka Jātaka is the fourth.
